ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Discrete mathematical tools for computer science: graph theory and combinatorics were most important concepts covered.
Basic concepts of graph theory, predicate logic, counting etc.
This course will teach you a little bit of all things discrete math. You'll pick up combinatorics, induction, logic, and more.
I learned about the fundamentals of discrete math.
different concepts in discrete mathematics and their application in mathematics.
I learned the basics of discrete math and proofs
None
introductory proof-writing, logic, probability, graphs
I learned a lot about discrete math including logic, sets, proofs, number theory, and more.
I gained a surface-level overview of several topics in discrete math, including logic, modular arithmetic, graph theory, and counting.
Lots of binary type concepts. Good introduction to the math constraints on a computer.
I have learned how Pests are essential in class understanding. Also, how important is it to go through the notes after a lecture.

I gained a working knowledge of various topics within discrete math such as propositional logic, logical operators, basic set theory, basic graph theory, div and mod operators, relations and characteristics about relations, and more that gives the foundation for some of the math needed within the field of computer science.
Knowledge of basic logic operators, writing proofs, and other CS-related math techniques such as modular arithmetic and graph theory.
some basic discrete math skills
Elementary topics in discrete math
Discrete mathematics, number theory, graph theory,  predicate logic, proof by induction
Discrete math in a CS context

We learned about:
Injective, bijective functions
Graphs
Number theory and counting principles
Modular arithmetic
Relations etc.
Great overview of proofs, logic, set/number theory, and discrete math in general.
The basic elements of discrete math such as proofs, logic, set theory, graph theory, and combinatorics
Better understanding of proof based math.
Knowledge of counting, probability, graphs, etc.
I learned a lot about discrete math!
proof writing, discrete math concepts
This course was useful as an introduction to discrete mathematics. I learned a lot about number, graph, and set theory.
a rough awareness of concepts in propositional logic, number theory, and a tiny bit of graph theory
It gave an introduction to several mathematical tools that show up in computer science.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lectures were solid, office hours hosted by ULAs were very helpful, psets were sometimes quite confusing but overall were manageable.

strength: The pace is appropriate and the examples provided during class are helpful for digesting the ideas.
weakness: A bit too easy.

The instructor did not hold regular office hours and did not record lectures. Studying felt 100% reliant on notes since the department did not approve of ULA lead office hours or review sessions during the exam week. 
Course material was pretty decent though. Wish we got to RSA encryption.

The class was always very consistent: the psets were all similar, the class itself was taught on a blackboard, and the exams were digestible given the practice ones. Still, I found it very hard to focus during lectures because of the way it was taught, and there was no way to go back and re-watch any recordings of the lecture or see the same examples on the board.
There are plenty of office hours sessions to help facilitate student learning. However, I wish that the lectures could have been recorded.
Prof was great at explaining the concepts but I hoped there were more examples of how they are applied.
None
Lectures were very clear and psets are short yet very helpful. I wish we had covered more material, but overall very good course

The major strength of this course is that it had very clear expectations and no surprises. The material taught in class was the only material you have to know and there is a weekly problem set that really captured all of the relevant topics. The only improvement I would make is that the tests were quite easy making the curve very difficult if you make any stupid mistakes. I would rather have very difficult tests where scoring in the 70s is an A rather than easy tests where making one mistake drops you to an A-.
A little bit more content on how what we are learning is implemented in the real world would be cool.

None of the classes were recorded, so this made it really difficult to catch up if you missed a day since the class material tended to transition very quickly. That being said, the class material itself was quite interesting, as it provides a good purview of multiple mathematical topics.
I think the Professor is going too fast on the material, but overall the Professor teaches the material good

The strengths of the course include the organization of the course, the number of resources provided for the course, the vast amount of office hours available, and the problem sets that require a lot of thought but help you to understand the concepts more deeply. The weaknesses of the course are that quite often, the problem sets covered topics that weren't covered in great detail in class, which made them pretty challenging and required help from the TAs more often than not, and that the resources available for the final exam review weren't as comprehensive as for the midterm, which made preparing more difficult.
More office hour times especially during reading week would be helpful. The final was unexpectedly hard and not comparable to the midterm or problem sets assigned.

The course material was taught with many examples, which was perfect for me. Learning through examples is a great way to really understand the concepts and puts you in a much better position to tackle the problem sets and exams.
this covers a lot of content without much depth in any of it
Well organized since there's not too much content. More of the course could be digitized considering the nature of the content

Strengths: the course had some amazing TAs who were always willing to explain difficult concepts. 

Weaknesses: lectures did not cover nearly enough detail to help with the homework and were structured to focus on a few theories that were important but had no direct application to the homework.

Strengths: fun psets, good OHs 
Weaknesses: lecture was unengaging

Strengths:
Prof Bridy is a clear lecturer
The topics covered until the midterm were taught really well

Weaknesses:
I feel like some of the material covered in the 75 min lectures could have been covered in 30 minutes
No good sample finals were made available -- everyone I know thought that preparing for the final was really difficult and challenging. There was not enough prep material, the textbook wasn't helpful, and I think the concepts taught in class didn't feel sufficient enough to enable us to answer a lot of the questions on the final. It is unfortunate because I am sure had we received more preparation time and material, or if the final was made into a 24 hour / take home final as done in the previous years, our understanding of the concepts would have been clearer and the performance better.
I think this course was excellent. Pacing and lectures were great, homeworks and exams were fair. Nothing to improve.
The content was presented in a very straightforward way and was well-presented. However, it could have been more engaging.
It is a lecture, so therefore has the immediate weakness of a huge class size; that said, there are a lot of available office hours and ULAs.
Professor Bridy is absolutely amazing with the clarity in which he teaches. All the problem sets are to the point and easily digestable. I had no problems with this course whatsoever.
strengths: clear lectures and assignments
The course moved at a good pace and was well-taught. We didn't end up getting to some material, but I thought we moved at a good pace that allowed me to balance my work in other classes.

Strengths - PSETs are good, appropriate level of challenge and relevant to the materials taught in the course

Weaknesses - the course doesn't really teach you *how* do to anything - much of lecture is spent walking through examples in a somewhat disorganized way, and the onus of extracting exactly what problem solving methods are being taught and when to use them falls entirely upon the student.
Also, the level of mathematical rigor required to do a "proof" was left very unclear, nor was it ever explained exactly what a "proof" is - two details that I felt were quite important for a proof-based class.

I think the two best ways this course needs to be improved are a) dedicate some time to teaching exactly what it means to "prove" something and decide on a consistent format for proofs, and b) instead of going through three very similar examples for a specific theorem, teach the theorem directly and then follow with one example.

Perhaps this was the intent of the course, but by covering so many topics, it ended up covering no topic in any real depth. Another issue is that the study of mathematical logic took up a disproportionate amount of time in my opinion, leaving little time for topics like combinatorics and number theory.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Course is one of the options to be a required course for the CS major, if it's not fulfilling a requirement for you probably not necessary.
Yes
This course, with its drawbacks, is still much more manageable than MATH 244. Recommend for CS Major + Certificate students.
I would only recommend this course if you are a computer science major. I still find it difficult  trying to apply the concepts we learned to the real world.
Only to students with a stem background, specifically, CS or Math
Definitely but perhaps the more mathematical discrete math course if they are looking to major in something that requires it.
None
Yes, need it for the CS major. If you've taken other proof based math classes I'd consider 244 over this class, but if you're schedule is already hectic this isn't too bad as a 5th
I would recommend this course as a prerequisite or just a fun math course that has a low workload and is not too difficult.
Yes, its good background.
If you are taking 202, you probably have to take it as a CS major, so yes.
Only if the student is planning to major in CS

I would probably only recommend this course if it's required for your major. It's not the most mind-changing class and you do definitely learn about some cool topics that apply to the real world, but if you're interested in discrete math and it's not required, I wouldn't recommend you take the class.
I would recommend the course, I found the topics covered to be interesting. Discrete mathematics is much different than subjects like calculus, and I enjoyed learning about the concepts.
only if you have to take it for a major
Yes
It's an easy discrete math class, not a CS class, but as long as you understand that yes
Yes, but only if it is required for your major.
Yes, if interested in mathematical CS

Yes
If you're a CS major, this is probably easier than MATH 244. 
It's a good class, but getting an A is definitely hard.
The concepts covered don't go too much into depth, and the level of difficulty on the midterm was easier than the psets and matched the difficulty of class questions. The second half of the class was a whole other ball game though. The concepts were covered quickly, we did interesting proofs but we barely got any practice on the types of questions to expect for the final. Psets were interesting but not the best at preparing you for the final.
Yes.
Yes, it's required for CS and not too difficult.
I personally would not recommend taking this class unless it's a major requirement.
I would recommend it if they were initially interested in mathematics or computer science.

Absolutely! If you ever did competitive math in high school this class will be exceptionally easy to follow, and overall I loved how it served as a primer into all of the different areas of discrete math.
yes if they would like a brief overview of various math topics ranging from number theory to combinatorics to graph theory
Yes, this class may be a bit slow, but it is straightforward and engaging as long as you take notes and pay attention in class.
Yes, it's a good course and Professor Bridy is good too

I would not recommend this course - it is somewhat disorganized and I felt that it was much more self-motivated learning than benefiting from good instruction. If you are genuinely interested in the topics I would recommend a more mathematically rigorous or proof-based class.
It is a good starting point before you jump into more advanced courses on discrete math and combinatorics.
